history.content:
@4475 Prof Sahai's answer and the comments might give you an interesting perspective.

-----

Its entirely up to you, your interests and your aspirations. I can tell that the vast majority of undergrads that end up in industry usually haven't taken any grad courses.
Its entirely up to you, your interests and your aspirations. I can tell that the vast majority of undergrads that end up in industry usually haven't taken any grad courses.

children.subject: So there's generally two kinds of grad courses: special topics courses or foundational material courses (yeah that's a bad name but deal with it). Special topics courses are exactly what they sound like, a professor has an idea of something special they'd like to teach for a semester and offer it in this form. Foundational material courses are really meant for learning the basic concepts needed to pursue further research (although they aren't that common in CS, my guess is because its still a relatively young field and there's been no organized effort to stop and think about pedagogy of material beyond undergrad stuff, but that's just my two cents) such as some of the grad EE courses. Most undergrads will take grad courses of the former variety, and I'd recommend that you check some of them out; if there's one on a topic that really interests you go for it. If you want tougher, more intensive grad courses related to ML, I'd recommend checking out Stat 210B. It's not an ML course per se, but a lot of the topics covered it in are important to ML (primarily concentration inequalities and how to use them). However I'd doubt you'd use anything covered in that course in an industry ML position unless its one meant for PhD's (i.e. a role more about theoretical ML than using it).

history.content: Are any grad courses worth taking for those interested in industry for SWE or Data Science / industry-oriented ML? Or do the undergrad courses cover pretty much everything you need to know for a future in industry? Just curious because I don't have any grad courses in my potential 4-year schedule right now, but there seems to be a fair amount of buzz amongst my peers (and on this Piazza) about taking graduate courses.
history.subject: Grad courses worth taking?
